hobby.message: Political literature still keeping you up?
Urban exploring with that homebrew again?
Analog photography still treating you right?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Yeah, still sweeping up there. Runs in cycles.
Doesn’t bother me much—my time’s spent underground.
Bit crowded lately, thanks to these coin stories.
Hobby’s urban tunnels. Easier when people don’t notice.
Still plenty of scans. Everyone’s nervous.
Doesn’t keep me topside though—I stick to tunnels, old data centers.
Lately, too many curious types down there hunting for coins.
Guess my hobby’s not as private as it used to be.
I just try to avoid attention and enjoy the quiet.
Scanners lighting up every other block now. Makes folk restless up there.
Doesn’t matter much, I prefer exploring city utility tunnels anyway.
Urban spelunking, you could call it. Always something broke, never dull.
Even got a little setup—maps, keys, a flask for long nights.
It’s different now. All those coin-hunters clogging the quiet spots.
Hard to enjoy the usual peace, but I manage.
Yeah, still scanning. Makes it easier for me to go unnoticed elsewhere.
My hobby’s hunting through sealed utility tunnels—old circuit bays, relay rooms, forgotten things.
Been at it years. I know which doors they never log.
Used to have the place to myself. Now it’s full of amateurs chasing coin rumors.
Saw kids crawling around a heat exchange last night. Made me miss the old peace.
I log bad wiring, patch leaks, bring home bits of history.
Suppose the noise topside just pushes curious folks deeper underground.
They are. Topside feels like a fishbowl now—everyone’s got eyes on them.
That’s why I stick to my hobby: exploring the underground—a maze most folks don’t believe exists.
Started out mapping power conduits for work, stayed for the quiet and the stories.
Been at it over a decade. Collected old keys, floor schematics, a few scars too.
Usually no company, just the hum of old systems and a flask.
But with those coins turning up, even the hidden tunnels aren’t safe from crowds.
Ran into two vanished faces just last week; neither seemed surprised to see me.
Used to be solitude, now it’s the city’s new rumor mill below the streets.
hobby_answer: Not boring yet. Not much to tell, really.
Been tougher to find peace in the tunnels lately.
Too many people poking around after that coin story.
City feels smaller when everyone’s hunting the same thing.
I mostly keep clear now.
Still good fun, but getting crowded these days.
People act like every tunnel hides a missing person now.
Since those coins showed up, can’t get a quiet spot.
Too many strangers asking questions, makes the work less pleasant.
I just stick to maintenance these days, nothing more.
Feels better to keep to myself.
No, never boring. Always something new underground.
Lately, more crowds than usual—everyone thinks they’re on a treasure hunt.
Since the coins appeared, every dark corridor has company.
Maintenance logs, old wires—suddenly everyone cares.
Had some kids tailing me, looking for secrets.
Tunnels aren’t the same refuge they were.
Makes you rethink your routes.
Never dull, trust me. City’s full of hidden layers.
Usually it’s quiet, now not so much—people chasing those coin rumors.
Even the old relay station had tourists last week.
Found some missing folks back in the tunnels—real ones, not stories.
Feels like the system’s cracks became everyone’s business overnight.
Had to mislead some amateur explorers to keep them out of trouble.
Makes me nostalgic for the days nobody cared.
Still, I’ll always find a quiet corner if I try.
Boring? Not in this city, not with what’s under our feet.
Started exploring to avoid the system’s eyes—old habit from Directorate days.
Back then, tunnels were peace—my place to think, maybe drink.
All changed when those ‘missing’ coins turned up.
Now every crawlspace has folks playing detective, hoping to find ghosts or proof.
Ran into a few vanished faces last week, hiding right where the Council forgot to look.
Had to hide my real records and steer people from dangerous shafts.
Feels like half the city’s awake suddenly, all chasing the same answers.
Guess I miss being alone down there, even if quiet’s overrated lately.
